Philosophy of Life.name: Existentialism
Philosophy of Life.description: Life has no inherent meaning, and individuals must create their own purpose through choices and actions.

Philosophy of Life.name: Absurdism
Philosophy of Life.description: There is a fundamental conflict between humans’ desire to find meaning and the universe’s indifference to providing it; meaning is found in embracing the absurd.

Philosophy of Life.name: Nihilism
Philosophy of Life.description: Life is devoid of intrinsic meaning, value, or purpose, and traditional moral and social structures are baseless.

Philosophy of Life.name: Stoicism
Philosophy of Life.description: The key to life is mastering one's emotions and reactions to external events, focusing on what can be controlled, and accepting what cannot.

Philosophy of Life.name: Hedonism
Philosophy of Life.description: The pursuit of pleasure and avoidance of pain are the primary or most important goals of human life.

Philosophy of Life.name: Eudaimonism
Philosophy of Life.description: The best life is one of flourishing, achieved by cultivating virtues and living according to reason.

Philosophy of Life.name: Epicureanism
Philosophy of Life.description: The goal of life is to achieve pleasure, which is attained through modest living, the pursuit of knowledge, and the avoidance of pain and fear.

Philosophy of Life.name: Utilitarianism
Philosophy of Life.description: The best action is the one that maximizes happiness or pleasure for the greatest number of people, while minimizing suffering.

Philosophy of Life.name: Humanism
Philosophy of Life.description: Humans can lead ethical and fulfilling lives without reliance on religious beliefs, emphasizing human dignity, reason, and compassion.

Philosophy of Life.name: Transcendentalism
Philosophy of Life.description: Individuals are inherently good and at their best when self-reliant, with true meaning found beyond the material world, in spiritual experiences and nature.

Philosophy of Life.name: Optimism
Philosophy of Life.description: Life is generally positive, and one should maintain hope and confidence in the future, expecting good outcomes.

Philosophy of Life.name: Pessimism
Philosophy of Life.description: Life is filled with suffering, and human existence tends toward hardship and disappointment; the world is fundamentally flawed.

Philosophy of Life.name: Pragmatism
Philosophy of Life.description: The value of ideas and actions lies in their practical consequences and benefits; meaning comes from what works in practice.

Philosophy of Life.name: Altruism
Philosophy of Life.description: The best life is one spent serving others, where selfless actions aimed at benefiting others bring true meaning and fulfillment.

Philosophy of Life.name: Libertarianism (Ethical)
Philosophy of Life.description: Life’s purpose is achieved through individual freedom, personal autonomy, and responsibility, with minimal interference from external forces.

Philosophy of Life.name: Absurd Heroism
Philosophy of Life.description: Although life is meaningless and absurd, one can find purpose through a defiant embrace of life and persistence in the face of futility.

Philosophy of Life.name: Buddhism (Philosophy)
Philosophy of Life.description: Life is a cycle of suffering caused by desire, and the path to enlightenment is through detachment, mindfulness, and ethical living.

Philosophy of Life.name: Taoism
Philosophy of Life.description: Life is best lived in harmony with the Tao (the way of nature), embracing simplicity, spontaneity, and non-resistance to the natural flow of events.

Philosophy of Life.name: Confucianism
Philosophy of Life.description: The best life is achieved through moral development, social harmony, respect for tradition, and fulfilling one’s role in society.

Philosophy of Life.name: Skepticism
Philosophy of Life.description: Life’s meaning cannot be definitively known, and one should approach claims of truth or purpose with doubt and critical thinking.

Philosophy of Life.name: Objectivism
Philosophy of Life.description: Life’s purpose is to pursue one’s own happiness through rational self-interest, with moral principles based on objective reality and reason.

Philosophy of Life.name: Relativism
Philosophy of Life.description: Meaning and morality are not absolute, but are shaped by cultural, societal, or individual perspectives.

Philosophy of Life.name: Perennialism
Philosophy of Life.description: All spiritual and philosophical traditions share a common truth, and the purpose of life is to seek this universal wisdom.

Philosophy of Life.name: Naturalism
Philosophy of Life.description: Life is explained by natural processes, without supernatural influence, and meaning is found through the understanding of nature and the universe.

Philosophy of Life.name: Existential Humanism
Philosophy of Life.description: Humans are free and responsible for creating their own meaning, and ethical living is guided by reason, compassion, and the rejection of unjust authorities.

Philosophy of Mind.name: Dualism
Philosophy of Mind.description: The mind and body are different in nature, and mental phenomena are non-physical.

Philosophy of Mind.name: Property Dualism
Philosophy of Mind.description: Mental properties are non-physical but emerge from physical substances, and consciousness cannot be reduced to brain processes.

Philosophy of Mind.name: Substance Dualism
Philosophy of Mind.description: Mind and body are different in nature and composed of different substances.

Philosophy of Mind.name: Monism
Philosophy of Mind.description: Reality is fundamentally composed of a single substance or principle, with both mind and body being aspects of the same underlying reality.

Philosophy of Mind.name: Idealism
Philosophy of Mind.description: Reality is fundamentally mental; physical objects exist only as perceptions, and the mind creates or shapes the physical world.

Philosophy of Mind.name: Reductive Physicalism
Philosophy of Mind.description: Mental states can be fully explained by physical processes, and the mind is identical to the brain.

Philosophy of Mind.name: Non-Reductive Physicalism
Philosophy of Mind.description: Mental states depend on but are not reducible to physical states, and consciousness arises from but is not identical to brain states.

Philosophy of Mind.name: Eliminative Materialism
Philosophy of Mind.description: Common-sense mental states like beliefs and desires do not exist.

Philosophy of Mind.name: Emergentism
Philosophy of Mind.description: Consciousness arises from complex physical systems but is not reducible to them, and mental properties emerge when physical systems reach a certain level of complexity.

Philosophy of Mind.name: Panpsychism
Philosophy of Mind.description: Consciousness is a fundamental aspect of all matter, and even the simplest particles possess some form of consciousness.

Philosophy of Mind.name: Epiphenomenalism
Philosophy of Mind.description: Mental events are caused by physical events but have no causal effects on the physical world, and consciousness is a byproduct of brain activity with no influence on physical behavior.

Philosophy of Mind.name: Psychophysical Parallelism
Philosophy of Mind.description: Mental and physical events run in parallel but do not causally interact, with mental processes mirroring physical ones without directly influencing them.

Philosophy of Mind.name: Quantum Mind
Philosophy of Mind.description: Consciousness arises from quantum processes within the brain, and understanding quantum mechanics is key to explaining the mind.

Philosophy of Mind.name: Occasionalism
Philosophy of Mind.description: God is the only true cause, and all interactions between mind and body are illusions, with God directly intervening to coordinate mental and physical events.

Philosophy of Mind.name: Integrated Information Theory
Philosophy of Mind.description: Consciousness is based on the amount of integrated information in a system, with higher levels of integration corresponding to higher levels of consciousness.

Philosophy of Mind.name: Global Workspace Theory
Philosophy of Mind.description: Consciousness arises from information being globally broadcasted to different parts of the brain, allowing it to be shared and integrated across various systems.

Philosophy of Mind.name: Functionalism
Philosophy of Mind.description: Mental states are defined by their functional roles, not by their physical makeup, and a mental state is characterized by what it does rather than what it is made of.

Philosophy of Mind.name: Methodological Behaviorism
Philosophy of Mind.description: Psychology should only study observable behavior, not internal mental states.

Philosophy of Mind.name: Radical Behaviorism
Philosophy of Mind.description: Mental states do not exist independently of behavior, and all behavior is the result of environmental conditioning.

Philosophy of Will.name: Libertarian Free Will
Philosophy of Will.description: Humans have genuine free will, meaning individuals are free to make choices that are not determined by prior causes or divine intervention.

Philosophy of Will.name: Compatibilism
Philosophy of Will.description: Free will is compatible with determinism, meaning that individuals can make free choices even if these choices are determined by prior causes.

Philosophy of Will.name: Determinism
Philosophy of Will.description: All events, including human actions, are determined by external causes.

Philosophy of Will.name: Hard Determinism
Philosophy of Will.description: Free will does not exist, and human actions are fully determined by external factors such as genetics, environment, and physical laws.

Philosophy of Will.name: Soft Determinism
Philosophy of Will.description: Human behavior is determined by prior causes, but free will can still exist in a limited sense, allowing for moral responsibility.

Philosophy of Will.name: Indeterminism
Philosophy of Will.description: Not all events are determined by preceding causes, and random or probabilistic factors play a role in the unfolding of events, allowing for free will.

Philosophy of Will.name: Voluntarism
Philosophy of Will.description: The will is the most fundamental aspect of human experience, taking precedence over intellect and emotions in determining actions.

Philosophy of Will.name: Schopenhauer's Will
Philosophy of Will.description: The will is a blind, irrational force that drives all human actions and underlies all of reality; human freedom is limited by this will.

Philosophy of Will.name: Nietzsche's Will to Power
Philosophy of Will.description: The driving force behind human behavior is the will to power, a fundamental instinct to assert and enhance one's strength and influence over oneself and the world.

Philosophy of Will.name: Kantian Free Will
Philosophy of Will.description: Free will is possible because humans are rational agents capable of acting according to moral laws they give to themselves, independent of external determinants.

Philosophy of Will.name: Existentialist Free Will
Philosophy of Will.description: Human beings have radical freedom and are responsible for creating their own essence through their choices, despite external conditions.

Philosophy of Will.name: Moral Responsibility and Free Will
Philosophy of Will.description: Free will is necessary for moral responsibility, meaning individuals are accountable for their actions because they freely choose them.

Philosophy of Will.name: Divine Will
Philosophy of Will.description: Human will is subject to the will of a divine being, and freedom consists in aligning human desires and actions with divine will.

Philosophy of Will.name: Psychological Determinism
Philosophy of Will.description: Human actions are determined by internal psychological factors, such as unconscious desires and drives, leaving little room for free will.

Philosophy of Will.name: Fatalism
Philosophy of Will.description: All events, including human choices, are predetermined and inevitable, meaning free will is illusory, and humans cannot change their fate.

Philosophy of Will.name: Pessimistic Voluntarism
Philosophy of Will.description: The human will is ultimately a source of suffering, as desires can never be fully satisfied, leading to frustration and existential despair.

Philosophy of Will.name: Will to Meaning (Logotherapy)
Philosophy of Will.description: Humans are driven by the will to find meaning in life, and this pursuit of meaning, rather than power or pleasure, is the primary motivating force.

Philosophy of Will.name: Free Will Skepticism
Philosophy of Will.description: Free will is an illusion, and humans do not have true freedom over their actions or decisions, which are shaped by biological, social, and psychological influences.

Philosophy of Will.name: Hegelian Will
Philosophy of Will.description: The individual will is part of a larger rational process in which freedom is realized through the development of ethical life and the state.

Philosophy of Will.name: Pragmatic Will
Philosophy of Will.description: The will is best understood as a tool for solving practical problems, with free will being meaningful only insofar as it allows for effective action.

Philosophy of Will.name: Will to Pleasure
Philosophy of Will.description: Humans are motivated primarily by the desire to experience pleasure and avoid pain, with free will serving to fulfill these desires.

Philosophy of Will.name: Biological Determinism
Philosophy of Will.description: Human will and behavior are determined by biological factors such as genetics and evolutionary pressures, leaving little to no room for free will.

Rationality.name: Effective Altruism
Rationality.description: Philanthropic efforts should be guided by reason and evidence to maximize the positive impact of charitable actions.

Rationality.name: Data-Driven Decision Making
Rationality.description: Decisions in business, politics, and personal life should be based on empirical data and statistical analysis rather than intuition or tradition.

Rationality.name: Rationalist Movement
Rationality.description: Beliefs and actions should be determined through a rigorous application of logic and evidence, with an emphasis on reducing cognitive biases and irrational thinking.

Rationality.name: Bayesian Epistemology
Rationality.description: Belief updates should follow Bayesian reasoning, where probabilities are assigned to hypotheses and updated as new evidence becomes available.

Rationality.name: AI Alignment
Rationality.description: Efforts to ensure that artificial intelligence systems are designed and programmed to act in accordance with human values and long-term interests, based on rational and ethical considerations.

Rationality.name: Longtermism
Rationality.description: Decisions should be made with the long-term future of humanity in mind, considering the potential impact on future generations over short-term gains.

Rationality.name: Moral Realism
Rationality.description: Objective moral facts exist independently of human beliefs, and rational inquiry can discover these facts.

Rationality.name: Quantified Self
Rationality.description: Personal decisions about health, fitness, and well-being should be based on data gathered from self-tracking devices and software, leading to more rational and optimized life choices.

Rationality.name: Predictive Processing
Rationality.description: The brain is fundamentally a prediction machine, constantly generating models of the world and updating them based on sensory input, offering a rational framework for understanding perception and cognition.

Rationality.name: Moral Uncertainty
Rationality.description: Ethical decision-making should account for uncertainty in moral theories, and rational approaches should be used to weigh different ethical frameworks against each other.

Rationality.name: Epistemic Vigilance
Rationality.description: Individuals should maintain high standards for evaluating the credibility of information sources, applying skepticism and reason to avoid being misled by misinformation or faulty logic.

Rationality.name: Digital Minimalism
Rationality.description: Technology use should be minimized and streamlined to maximize well-being and focus, based on a rational assessment of its benefits and harms.

Rationality.name: Simulation Hypothesis
Rationality.description: It is rational to consider the possibility that our reality could be a sophisticated simulation created by advanced technology.

Rationality.name: Effective Governance
Rationality.description: Political decisions should be made based on empirical evidence, cost-benefit analyses, and rational deliberation to optimize societal outcomes.

Rationality.name: Post-Rationalism
Rationality.description: While reason and logic are important, human cognition also involves emotion, culture, and intuition, which should be integrated with rationalist principles for a more holistic understanding.

Eating habits.name: Veganism
Eating habits.description: Animal products, including meat, dairy, and eggs, should not be consumed due to ethical, environmental, or health concerns.

Eating habits.name: Vegetarianism
Eating habits.description: Meat, fish, and poultry should be excluded from the diet, while dairy products and eggs are acceptable, for ethical, health, or environmental reasons.

Eating habits.name: Paleo Diet
Eating habits.description: The diet should consist primarily of meat, fish, vegetables, and fruits, while processed foods and grains should be excluded, following the presumed diet of early humans.

Eating habits.name: Keto Diet
Eating habits.description: A high-fat, low-carbohydrate diet is the best way to shift the body towards burning fat for energy, leading to weight loss and improved metabolic health.

Eating habits.name: Intermittent Fasting
Eating habits.description: Eating should be restricted to specific time windows or fasting periods to promote weight loss, metabolic health, and longevity.

Eating habits.name: Whole Food, Plant-Based Diet
Eating habits.description: Unprocessed or minimally processed plant foods, such as fruits, vegetables, legumes, and whole grains, should be the foundation of the diet, while animal products and processed foods should be avoided.

Eating habits.name: Omnivorism
Eating habits.description: A balanced diet that includes both plant and animal products is the most natural and healthy way to obtain a wide range of nutrients.

Eating habits.name: Locavorism
Eating habits.description: Food should be sourced locally to reduce the environmental impact of transportation and to support local farmers and economies.

Eating habits.name: Flexitarianism
Eating habits.description: A primarily plant-based diet, with occasional consumption of meat and animal products, is the best balance for health, environmental sustainability, and ethics.

Eating habits.name: Raw Food Diet
Eating habits.description: Uncooked, unprocessed foods, especially organic ones, are healthier because they retain more nutrients than cooked foods.

Eating habits.name: Fruitarianism
Eating habits.description: The diet should consist mainly of fruits, nuts, and seeds, excluding most other foods, as part of a spiritual, ethical, or health-driven lifestyle.

Eating habits.name: Carnivorism
Eating habits.description: Only animal products should be consumed, excluding all plant-based foods, as this diet is believed to be healthier and more natural.

Eating habits.name: Mindful Eating
Eating habits.description: Eating should be done with full awareness of the taste, texture, and sensations of food, with the goal of eating in response to hunger and not external cues.

Eating habits.name: Slow Food Movement
Eating habits.description: Food should be regionally-sourced, traditional, and sustainably produced, and meals should be enjoyed slowly, opposing the fast food culture.

Eating habits.name: Zero Waste Diet
Eating habits.description: The diet should minimize food waste by using all parts of ingredients, reducing packaging, and prioritizing sustainable and environmentally friendly sourcing.

Eating habits.name: Clean Eating
Eating habits.description: Only whole, unprocessed foods should be consumed, avoiding artificial ingredients, added sugars, and heavily processed products.

Eating habits.name: Ayurvedic Diet
Eating habits.description: Food choices should be tailored to an individual's body type (dosha) according to ancient Indian Ayurvedic principles to maintain health and balance.

Eating habits.name: Mediterranean Diet
Eating habits.description: The diet should be based on vegetables, fruits, whole grains, olive oil, and moderate amounts of fish and wine, following the traditional eating habits of Mediterranean cultures.

Eating habits.name: Gluten-Free Diet
Eating habits.description: Gluten-containing grains like wheat, barley, and rye should be excluded from the diet, particularly for those with gluten intolerance or celiac disease.

Eating habits.name: High-Protein Diet
Eating habits.description: A diet high in protein, including lean meats, eggs, and legumes, is essential for supporting muscle growth, weight loss, or athletic performance.

Religious Philosophy.name: Atheism
Religious Philosophy.description: There are no deities, and belief in gods is unfounded.

Religious Philosophy.name: Agnosticism
Religious Philosophy.description: It is impossible to know whether deities exist or not.

Religious Philosophy.name: Theism
Religious Philosophy.description: At least one deity exists and plays a role in the universe.

Religious Philosophy.name: Deism
Religious Philosophy.description: A creator deity exists but does not intervene in the universe or human affairs.

Religious Philosophy.name: Pantheism
Religious Philosophy.description: God and the universe are the same, and everything in existence is a manifestation of the divine.

Religious Philosophy.name: Polytheism
Religious Philosophy.description: There are multiple deities, each with different roles and powers governing various aspects of the universe.

Religious Philosophy.name: Monotheism
Religious Philosophy.description: There is only one deity who is all-powerful and governs the universe.

Religious Philosophy.name: Henotheism
Religious Philosophy.description: While multiple deities may exist, one deity is supreme or worthy of worship above the others.

Religious Philosophy.name: Animism
Religious Philosophy.description: All objects, places, and creatures possess a distinct spiritual essence, and nature is inhabited by spirits.

Religious Philosophy.name: Syncretism
Religious Philosophy.description: Different religious beliefs and practices can be combined into a cohesive system.

Religious Philosophy.name: Fundamentalism
Religious Philosophy.description: Religious texts should be interpreted literally, and society should be governed by strict adherence to religious laws and values.

Religious Philosophy.name: Exclusivism
Religious Philosophy.description: Only one particular religion is the true faith, and all other religions are false or misguided.

Religious Philosophy.name: Secular Humanism
Religious Philosophy.description: Human beings can lead ethical, meaningful lives without reliance on religious beliefs or deities.

Religious Philosophy.name: Spiritualism
Religious Philosophy.description: There is a non-physical reality or dimension, and individuals can connect with it or receive guidance from spiritual beings or forces.

Religious Philosophy.name: Universalism
Religious Philosophy.description: All religions contain elements of truth, and there is a universal spiritual reality that transcends individual religious systems.

Religious Philosophy.name: Esotericism
Religious Philosophy.description: Only a select few are capable of seeking and understanding hidden spiritual knowledge that leads to a deeper understanding of the divine and the cosmos.

Religious Philosophy.name: Religious Pluralism
Religious Philosophy.description: No single religion holds all the truth, and multiple religions can offer valid paths to spiritual understanding or enlightenment.

Politics.name: Liberalism
Politics.description: The government should protect civil liberties and individual freedoms while limiting its intervention in personal and economic matters.

Politics.name: Conservatism
Politics.description: Society should prioritize tradition, stability, and gradual change, with limited government intervention in markets and personal lives.

Politics.name: Communism
Politics.description: The state should be governed by the working class, through a single-party system, aiming to eliminate class distinctions and centralize political power to achieve a classless, stateless society.

Politics.name: Libertarianism
Politics.description: Individuals should be free to make their own choices, with minimal government interference in both personal and economic matters.

Politics.name: Anarchism
Politics.description: All forms of hierarchical government and authority should be abolished in favor of self-managed, stateless societies.

Politics.name: Fascism
Politics.description: A strong, centralized government should prioritize national unity and authority, even at the expense of individual freedoms.

Politics.name: Nazism
Politics.description: The state should be led by a totalitarian regime based on racial purity, authoritarian control, and the suppression of political opposition.

Politics.name: Progressivism
Politics.description: The government should actively reform society to promote social justice, economic equality, and environmental sustainability.

Politics.name: Authoritarianism
Politics.description: Strong, centralized control by a single leader or ruling party is necessary to maintain order and enforce societal norms.

Politics.name: Environmentalism
Politics.description: Government policies should prioritize the protection of the environment and address issues like climate change and sustainability.

Politics.name: Populism
Politics.description: The interests of ordinary people should be prioritized over those of elites or established institutions in political decision-making.

Politics.name: Nationalism
Politics.description: A nation’s interests and culture should be prioritized over international cooperation and global governance.

Politics.name: Social Democracy
Politics.description: The government should combine democratic governance with a strong welfare state, regulating the economy to ensure social welfare and reduce inequality.

Politics.name: Libertarian Socialism
Politics.description: Both centralized government and capitalist economic systems should be abolished in favor of decentralized, self-managed communities.

Politics.name: Monarchism
Politics.description: Political power should be vested in a monarchy, with a king or queen either ruling directly or serving as a symbolic figurehead.

Politics.name: Theocracy
Politics.description: Government policies should be guided by religious principles, with religious leaders having significant influence in governance.

Politics.name: Technocracy
Politics.description: Experts, particularly scientists and engineers, should govern societies based on data and technical expertise rather than political ideologies.

Politics.name: Democratic Socialism
Politics.description: Key industries should be publicly owned and controlled through democratic governance, ensuring both economic equality and individual freedoms.

Politics.name: Traditionalism
Politics.description: Society should adhere to long-established cultural, moral, and religious values, resisting modern changes and preserving traditional institutions.

Economics.name: Capitalism
Economics.description: The economy should be driven by private ownership and free markets, with minimal government intervention, allowing competition to promote innovation and efficiency.

Economics.name: Socialism
Economics.description: The government should own or control the major means of production and distribution to reduce inequality and ensure that resources are fairly distributed.

Economics.name: Communism (Economics)
Economics.description: The economy should be collectively owned, with no private property, and resources and wealth should be distributed equally among all members of society.

Economics.name: Keynesian Economics
Economics.description: The government should actively intervene in the economy, particularly during recessions, by increasing public spending and lowering taxes to stimulate demand.

Economics.name: Laissez-Faire Economics
Economics.description: The government should have no role in regulating the economy, allowing individuals and businesses to operate freely without intervention.

Economics.name: Monetarism
Economics.description: Economic stability is best achieved by controlling the money supply, and government intervention should focus primarily on managing inflation rather than direct spending.

Economics.name: Supply-Side Economics
Economics.description: Economic growth is best stimulated by lowering taxes and reducing regulation, particularly for businesses and the wealthy, to encourage investment and production.

Economics.name: Mixed Economy
Economics.description: The economy should combine elements of capitalism and socialism, with private enterprise operating alongside government regulations and social welfare programs.

Economics.name: Neoliberalism
Economics.description: Free markets, privatization, and deregulation should be promoted, with minimal government involvement in the economy, to foster global economic growth and development.

Economics.name: Libertarian Economics
Economics.description: Economic freedom is paramount, and government involvement in markets, taxation, and regulation should be as limited as possible.

Economics.name: Georgism
Economics.description: Economic rent from land and natural resources should be the primary source of public revenue, while other forms of taxation should be minimized or eliminated.

Economics.name: Behavioral Economics
Economics.description: Economic policies should consider psychological factors and human behavior, which often deviate from rational decision-making, to better understand and predict economic outcomes.

Economics.name: Austrian Economics
Economics.description: The economy functions best when left to free market forces, with minimal government intervention, and focuses on individual choice and entrepreneurship.

Economics.name: Degrowth
Economics.description: Economic growth should be scaled back to achieve environmental sustainability and improve quality of life, emphasizing local economies and reduced consumption.

Economics.name: Circular Economy
Economics.description: The economy should minimize waste by reusing, repairing, and recycling materials, promoting sustainable production and consumption to preserve resources.

Economics.name: Post-Keynesian Economics
Economics.description: The economy is inherently unstable, and government intervention is necessary to manage demand, prevent recessions, and address issues like inequality.

Economics.name: Marxism
Economics.description: Capitalism inevitably leads to exploitation and inequality, and the working class should overthrow the capitalist system to establish a society where the means of production are collectively owned.

Economics.name: Malthusianism
Economics.description: Population growth should be controlled to prevent overconsumption of resources, which could lead to widespread poverty and environmental degradation.

Economics.name: Social Market Economy
Economics.description: The economy should be market-based, but the government should ensure social welfare and equitable wealth distribution through regulation and social programs.

Economics.name: Protectionism
Economics.description: The government should protect domestic industries from foreign competition through tariffs, quotas, and other trade barriers to promote local economic growth.

Economics.name: Free Trade
Economics.description: International trade should be free from tariffs and other restrictions, allowing goods and services to flow across borders without government interference.

Economics.name: Universal Basic Income (UBI)
Economics.description: The government should provide all citizens with a regular, unconditional income to ensure basic economic security and reduce poverty.

Economics.name: Participatory Economics
Economics.description: Economic decisions should be made collectively through democratic participation, with workers and consumers having a direct say in how resources are allocated.

Personal Finance.name: Frugality
Personal Finance.description: Individuals should spend as little money as possible, prioritizing saving over consumption and avoiding unnecessary expenses.

Personal Finance.name: Conscious Spending
Personal Finance.description: People should spend money mindfully, making purchases that align with their values and long-term goals, while avoiding impulse buys.

Personal Finance.name: Investing for Growth
Personal Finance.description: Individuals should prioritize long-term investments in stocks, real estate, or businesses to grow wealth over time.

Personal Finance.name: FIRE (Financial Independence, Retire Early)
Personal Finance.description: People should save aggressively and invest wisely to achieve financial independence and retire early, avoiding traditional career paths.

Personal Finance.name: Debt-Free Living
Personal Finance.description: Individuals should avoid taking on debt and prioritize paying off any existing debts to maintain financial freedom and security.

Personal Finance.name: Index Fund Investing
Personal Finance.description: Investing in low-cost index funds is the best strategy for long-term wealth growth, providing diversification and minimal management costs.

Personal Finance.name: High-Risk, High-Reward Investing
Personal Finance.description: Investing in high-risk assets like cryptocurrencies, startups, or speculative stocks can yield large returns, but individuals must be prepared for potential losses.

Personal Finance.name: Passive Income
Personal Finance.description: Individuals should prioritize building streams of passive income, such as real estate, dividend-paying stocks, or digital products, to achieve financial freedom.

Personal Finance.name: Budgeting
Personal Finance.description: People should carefully track income and expenses to create a budget that aligns with their financial goals and helps control spending.

Personal Finance.name: Pay Yourself First
Personal Finance.description: Individuals should prioritize saving a portion of their income before paying for any other expenses, ensuring consistent contributions toward financial goals.

Personal Finance.name: Credit Utilization
Personal Finance.description: Managing credit card use by keeping balances low and paying off debts on time is essential for maintaining a good credit score and financial health.

Personal Finance.name: Diversification
Personal Finance.description: Investments should be spread across multiple asset classes, industries, and regions to reduce risk and improve potential returns.

Personal Finance.name: Living Below Your Means
Personal Finance.description: Individuals should consistently spend less than they earn, even as income increases, to build wealth over time.

Personal Finance.name: Speculative Trading
Personal Finance.description: Engaging in high-risk trades, like options or futures, can generate large profits, but individuals must be prepared for significant losses.

Personal Finance.name: Real Estate Investment
Personal Finance.description: Investing in real estate properties for rental income or appreciation is a solid strategy for building long-term wealth.

Personal Finance.name: Automated Saving
Personal Finance.description: Setting up automatic transfers to savings or investment accounts helps ensure consistent saving without relying on willpower.

Personal Finance.name: Micro-Investing
Personal Finance.description: Using apps or services to invest small amounts of money frequently can help individuals build investment portfolios gradually.

Personal Finance.name: Tax Optimization
Personal Finance.description: Individuals should strategically use tax-advantaged accounts, deductions, and credits to reduce tax liabilities and increase savings.

Personal Finance.name: Ethical Investing
Personal Finance.description: People should invest in companies and funds that align with their ethical values, such as environmental sustainability or social justice.

Personal Finance.name: Hedging
Personal Finance.description: Using financial instruments like options or other derivatives to protect investments from adverse market movements is a strategy for managing risk.

Personal Finance.name: Dollar-Cost Averaging
Personal Finance.description: Investing a fixed amount of money at regular intervals, regardless of market conditions, is a strategy to minimize risk and reduce the impact of market volatility.

Personal Finance.name: Value Investing
Personal Finance.description: Investing in stocks that are undervalued based on fundamental analysis can provide significant returns as the market corrects their prices.

Personal Finance.name: Lifestyle Inflation
Personal Finance.description: As income increases, people should avoid increasing their spending proportionally, and instead focus on saving or investing the extra income.

Personal Finance.name: Financial Independence
Personal Finance.description: Individuals should aim to accumulate enough wealth to support their lifestyle without needing to work, allowing for financial freedom.

Personal Finance.name: Cryptocurrency Investment
Personal Finance.description: Investing in cryptocurrencies can provide high returns but comes with significant risk due to market volatility and regulatory uncertainty.

Personal Finance.name: Leveraged Investing
Personal Finance.description: Borrowing money to invest can amplify potential returns, but it also increases the risk of larger losses if the investment underperforms.

Personal Finance.name: Insurance Planning
Personal Finance.description: Comprehensive insurance planning, including health, life, and property insurance, is essential for protecting against unforeseen financial risks.

Personal Finance.name: Cash-Only Budgeting
Personal Finance.description: Using only cash for expenses and avoiding credit entirely is a method for controlling spending and avoiding debt.

Personal Finance.name: Credit Card Hacking
Personal Finance.description: Using credit cards strategically to earn rewards, cash back, or travel points without incurring interest can be a savvy financial move if done responsibly.

Ecology.name: Deep Ecology
Ecology.description: All living beings have inherent value, and humans must radically change their relationship with the natural world to prevent ecological degradation.

Ecology.name: Ecofeminism
Ecology.description: Environmental degradation and the oppression of women are interconnected, and ecological sustainability can only be achieved through gender equality.

Ecology.name: Anthropocentrism
Ecology.description: Humans are the most important beings, and the environment is valuable primarily for its utility to human needs and development.

Ecology.name: Biocentrism
Ecology.description: All living organisms, not just humans, have moral standing, and human actions should respect the intrinsic value of all life forms.

Ecology.name: Ecocentrism
Ecology.description: The ecosystem as a whole has intrinsic value, and ethical considerations should focus on maintaining the integrity and health of ecological systems.

Ecology.name: Environmental Pragmatism
Ecology.description: Environmental problems should be addressed through practical, solution-oriented approaches rather than adhering strictly to ideological positions.

Ecology.name: Social Ecology
Ecology.description: Ecological crises stem from hierarchical and exploitative social structures, and solving environmental problems requires addressing social injustices.

Ecology.name: Gaia Hypothesis
Ecology.description: The Earth and its biological systems behave as a single, self-regulating organism, and human activities can disrupt this balance.

Ecology.name: Sustainability
Ecology.description: Ecological sustainability is the ability to meet the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs.

Ecology.name: Green Anarchism
Ecology.description: Ecological destruction is tied to political hierarchies and centralized power, and environmental sustainability requires decentralized, non-hierarchical social structures.

Ecology.name: Conservationism
Ecology.description: Natural resources should be managed and conserved for future generations, often through regulated human use and preservation of natural habitats.

Ecology.name: Preservationism
Ecology.description: Nature should be protected in its pristine state, free from human interference, emphasizing the intrinsic value of wilderness.

Ecology.name: Eco-Marxism
Ecology.description: Environmental issues are rooted in capitalist exploitation of nature, and ecological sustainability requires transforming the economic system.

Ecology.name: Stewardship
Ecology.description: Humans have a moral duty to care for and manage the Earth responsibly, acting as stewards of the environment.

Ecology.name: Ecotheology
Ecology.description: Religious and spiritual teachings emphasize the sacredness of nature and call for humanity to protect and preserve the environment.

Ecology.name: Eco-Socialism
Ecology.description: Ecological sustainability can only be achieved through collective ownership and management of resources, rejecting capitalist exploitation of nature.

Ecology.name: Anthropocene
Ecology.description: The current geological era is defined by significant human impact on the Earth's ecosystems, and humans must adapt their behaviors to mitigate further damage.

Ecology.name: Land Ethic
Ecology.description: Humans are part of a larger ecological community, and ethical decisions should be made with the well-being of the land and its ecosystems in mind.

Ecology.name: Permaculture
Ecology.description: Human activities should mimic natural ecosystems to create sustainable agricultural and living systems that regenerate the environment.

Ecology.name: Holism
Ecology.description: The environment should be understood as a whole system, where all parts are interconnected, and ecological problems should be addressed with this holistic view.

Ecology.name: Ecopsychology
Ecology.description: Human well-being is deeply connected to nature, and ecological destruction contributes to psychological distress; healing requires reconnecting with the Earth.

Ecology.name: Climate Justice
Ecology.description: The impacts of climate change disproportionately affect marginalized communities, and addressing the climate crisis requires social and environmental justice.

Ecology.name: Posthumanism (Ecology)
Ecology.description: Humans should transcend anthropocentrism and recognize the value of non-human life and ecosystems, advocating for a more inclusive environmental ethics.

Ecology.name: Rewilding
Ecology.description: Human interventions in nature should be minimized, allowing ecosystems to return to their natural, wild state for greater biodiversity and ecological balance.

Ecology.name: Environmental Virtue Ethics
Ecology.description: Humans should cultivate virtues like humility, care, and respect for nature to live in harmony with the environment.

Ecology.name: Technogaianism
Ecology.description: Belief that emerging technologies can help restore Earth's environment.

Software Development.name: Software Minimalism
Software Development.description: A philosophy that advocates for creating software that is as simple and lightweight as possible, reducing unnecessary features, complexity, and bloat, while focusing on essential functionality.

Software Development.name: KISS (Keep It Simple, Stupid)
Software Development.description: A design philosophy that advocates for simplicity, avoiding unnecessary complexity in both the design and coding of software.

Software Development.name: DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself)
Software Development.description: A principle that promotes reducing redundancy in code by ensuring that information is not duplicated, emphasizing code reuse.

Software Development.name: YAGNI (You Aren't Gonna Need It)
Software Development.description: A principle advising developers to avoid adding unnecessary features or functionality until they are absolutely needed.

Software Development.name: Microservices Architecture
Software Development.description: An architectural style that structures an application as a collection of small, independent services that communicate with each other, offering flexibility and scalability.

Software Development.name: Monolithic Architecture
Software Development.description: An architectural style where all the functions of an application are tightly integrated into a single unit, which can be simpler to develop but harder to scale.

Software Development.name: Serverless Architecture
Software Development.description: A cloud computing model where developers focus on writing code, while cloud services automatically manage server infrastructure, scaling, and execution.

Software Development.name: Pair Programming
Software Development.description: A practice where two developers work together at one workstation, with one writing code and the other reviewing it in real-time, fostering collaboration and code quality.

Software Development.name: No-Code Development
Software Development.description: Applications should be created using visual tools and pre-built components, allowing users with no programming knowledge to build software without writing any code.

Software Development.name: Low-Code Development
Software Development.description: Applications should be built using platforms that require minimal coding, allowing developers to create software faster by leveraging pre-built components while still customizing parts of the code.

Software Development.name: LLM-Generated Software
Software Development.description: Software can be generated by large language models, automating parts of the development process and reducing the need for human coding, with potential impacts on efficiency, creativity, and the role of developers.

Software Methodology.name: Extreme Programming (XP)
Software Methodology.description: A development methodology that emphasizes rapid development cycles, continuous testing, and close customer collaboration to improve software quality.

Software Methodology.name: Test-Driven Development (TDD)
Software Methodology.description: A development practice where tests are written before code, ensuring that new code passes predefined tests and meets specific requirements.

Software Methodology.name: Behavior-Driven Development (BDD)
Software Methodology.description: An approach to development that defines software behavior in terms of user interaction and business outcomes, using natural language to describe tests.

Software Methodology.name: DevOps
Software Methodology.description: A culture and practice that unites software development and IT operations to improve collaboration and streamline the process of deploying code.

Software Methodology.name: Waterfall Development
Software Methodology.description: A traditional software development model where each phase is completed sequentially, and progress flows in one direction, from requirements to maintenance.

Software Methodology.name: Lean Software Development
Software Methodology.description: An approach that emphasizes efficiency by eliminating waste, improving flow, and delivering value quickly with minimal overhead.

Software Methodology.name: Agile Development
Software Methodology.description: A development methodology emphasizing flexibility, collaboration, and iterative releases to quickly adapt to changing requirements.

Software Methodology.name: Scrum
Software Methodology.description: An Agile framework that uses short development cycles (sprints) and daily stand-up meetings to incrementally deliver software and adjust to feedback.

Software Methodology.name: Continuous Integration (CI)
Software Methodology.description: A development practice where code changes are frequently integrated into a shared repository and tested automatically to detect integration issues early.

Software Methodology.name: Continuous Deployment (CD)
Software Methodology.description: A practice where code is automatically deployed to production as soon as it passes testing, ensuring rapid delivery of new features and bug fixes.

Software Licensing.name: Open Source Software
Software Licensing.description: Software source code should be made publicly available.

Software Licensing.name: Free Software
Software Licensing.description: Software should be freely used, modified, and shared by users.

Software Licensing.name: Copyleft Software
Software Licensing.description: Software licenses should ensure that derivative works are also freely available and cannot be made proprietary.

Software Licensing.name: Proprietary Software
Software Licensing.description: Software that is privately owned, with restrictions on how it can be used, modified, and distributed, often used to protect commercial interests.

Software Licensing.name: Permissive Licensing
Software Licensing.description: Software licenses should allow users to freely modify and redistribute the code, including in proprietary software, with minimal restrictions.

Software Licensing.name: Creative Commons for Software
Software Licensing.description: Software should be licensed under Creative Commons, giving users flexible rights to share, remix, or use code in specific ways while respecting the author's terms.

Software Licensing.name: Public Domain Software
Software Licensing.description: Software should be placed in the public domain, allowing anyone to use, modify, and distribute it without any restrictions or obligations.

Software Licensing.name: SaaS Licensing
Software Licensing.description: Software can be licensed as a service, where users subscribe to access the software, but do not own or control the underlying code.

Software Licensing.name: Dual Licensing
Software Licensing.description: Software can be made available under two licenses, allowing users to choose between open-source or proprietary licensing based on their needs.

Software Licensing.name: EULA (End User License Agreement)
Software Licensing.description: Software can be licensed with strict usage terms defined in an EULA, which users must agree to before using the software, protecting the vendor’s rights.

Software Licensing.name: Viral Licenses
Software Licensing.description: Software licensed under viral licenses requires that any derivative works also be distributed under the same license, ensuring that the license terms 'spread' to all future versions.

Software Licensing.name: Parody Licenses
Software Licensing.description: Software is licensed under terms that parody traditional licenses, often using exaggerated or humorous conditions to make a point about licensing practices or software freedom.

Intellectual Property.name: Copyright
Intellectual Property.description: Intellectual property should be strictly protected, with creators holding exclusive rights to control the use, distribution, and modification of their work.

Intellectual Property.name: Creative Commons
Intellectual Property.description: Creators should voluntarily license their works under flexible terms, allowing others to use, modify, and distribute the content under specific conditions.

Intellectual Property.name: Patent System
Intellectual Property.description: Inventors should be granted exclusive rights to their inventions for a limited time, encouraging innovation by providing economic incentives.

Intellectual Property.name: Anti-Patent Movement
Intellectual Property.description: The patent system stifles innovation and should be abolished, as it creates monopolies and limits access to important technologies.

Intellectual Property.name: Fair Use Doctrine
Intellectual Property.description: Certain uses of copyrighted material, such as for criticism, education, or parody, should be allowed without needing the creator's permission.

Intellectual Property.name: Piracy as Protest
Intellectual Property.description: Piracy of digital content is a legitimate form of protest against the restrictive nature of current intellectual property laws.

Intellectual Property.name: Public Domain Advocacy
Intellectual Property.description: Intellectual property should eventually enter the public domain.

Intellectual Property.name: Digital Rights Management (DRM)
Intellectual Property.description: Technological measures like DRM can be implemented to prevent unauthorized copying and distribution of digital content.

Intellectual Property.name: Right to Repair
Intellectual Property.description: Consumers should have the legal right to repair their own devices or have them repaired by third parties.

Intellectual Property.name: Moral Rights of Authors
Intellectual Property.description: Authors should retain moral rights over their work, even after selling the copyright, ensuring that their work is not distorted or used inappropriately.

Intellectual Property.name: Copyleft
Intellectual Property.description: Intellectual property licenses should ensure that derivative works remain free and open, preventing proprietary restrictions on modified versions.

Intellectual Property.name: Trademark Protection
Intellectual Property.description: Trademarks should be protected to prevent confusion and fraud, ensuring that consumers can trust the origin and quality of branded goods.

Intellectual Property.name: Patent Troll Reform
Intellectual Property.description: Laws should be reformed to prevent 'patent trolls' from exploiting the patent system by filing frivolous lawsuits against legitimate inventors and businesses.

Art.name: Minimalism
Art.description: A movement focused on simplicity and the reduction of form and content, where artworks emphasize purity of design and reject excess.

Art.name: Abstract Expressionism
Art.description: An art movement that emphasizes spontaneous, automatic, or subconscious creation, rejecting realism in favor of abstraction and emotional expression.

Art.name: Realism
Art.description: An artistic approach that aims to depict subjects as they are in everyday life, without embellishment or interpretation, often in opposition to abstract or idealized styles.

Art.name: Surrealism
Art.description: A movement that seeks to express the unconscious mind, combining dream-like imagery with reality to create fantastical, illogical scenes.

Art.name: Conceptual Art
Art.description: An art form where the idea or concept behind the artwork takes precedence over its aesthetic or material form, often challenging traditional notions of art.

Art.name: Impressionism
Art.description: A movement focused on capturing the effects of light and atmosphere, using visible brush strokes and often depicting scenes from everyday life.

Art.name: Pop Art
Art.description: An art movement that draws inspiration from popular culture, mass media, and consumerism, often using imagery from advertisements, comic books, and everyday objects.

Art.name: Futurism
Art.description: A movement that celebrates technology, speed, and the dynamism of modern life, often depicting motion and rejecting traditional forms and values.

Art.name: Dadaism
Art.description: An anti-art movement that rejects traditional aesthetics and conventions, often embracing absurdity, chaos, and spontaneity to challenge the norms of art and society.

Art.name: Art Brut (Outsider Art)
Art.description: A movement that celebrates the work of self-taught, untrained artists, often focusing on raw, unrefined expression outside of traditional art institutions.

Art.name: Street Art
Art.description: A form of public, often unauthorized, art that includes graffiti and murals, used to challenge the boundaries of traditional art spaces and convey social and political messages.

Art.name: Art for Art's Sake
Art.description: A philosophy that argues art should be valued for its beauty and aesthetic qualities alone, without any need for moral, political, or social justification.

Art.name: Hyperrealism
Art.description: A genre of art in which the artist seeks to create artwork that mimics high-definition reality, often indistinguishable from photographs.

Art.name: Romanticism
Art.description: A movement that emphasizes emotion, individualism, and the sublime in nature, often in contrast to the rationalism of the Enlightenment.

Art.name: Cubism
Art.description: A revolutionary movement that breaks subjects into geometric forms, representing multiple viewpoints at once and rejecting traditional perspectives.

Art.name: Expressionism
Art.description: A movement that seeks to express emotional experience rather than physical reality, often using exaggerated colors and distorted forms to convey inner turmoil or angst.

Art.name: Constructivism
Art.description: A movement that emerged in Russia, emphasizing art as a tool for social and political purposes, with a focus on abstract, geometric forms and industrial materials.

Art.name: Modernism
Art.description: A broad movement that embraces innovation, rejecting traditional forms and conventions in favor of experimentation and new modes of expression.

Art.name: Postmodernism
Art.description: A reaction against modernism, questioning notions of originality, authorship, and the grand narratives of history, often embracing irony, parody, and pastiche.

Art.name: Metamodernism
Art.description: Art should oscillate between modernist sincerity and postmodern irony, blending emotional depth with playful ambiguity to reflect the complexity of contemporary experience.

Art.name: Performance Art
Art.description: An art form that combines visual art with live performance, where the body of the artist or others becomes the medium, often emphasizing interaction and temporality.

Art.name: Socially Engaged Art
Art.description: An approach to art that emphasizes direct interaction with social issues, often involving collaboration with communities and focusing on activism and political change.

Art.name: Symbolism
Art.description: A movement that uses symbolic imagery to represent ideas, emotions, or states of mind, often focusing on mysticism, spirituality, and the imagination.

Art.name: Folk Art
Art.description: Art created by people with no formal training, often reflecting traditional culture, community values, and everyday life.

Art.name: Bauhaus
Art.description: A school of design and architecture that emphasizes function and simplicity, integrating art, craft, and technology to create a unified modern aesthetic.

Art.name: Abstract Art
Art.description: Art that does not attempt to represent reality, instead using shapes, colors, and forms to achieve its effect, often focusing on the emotional or conceptual.

Art.name: Naive Art
Art.description: A style of art characterized by a childlike simplicity and lack of formal technique, often created by self-taught artists.

Inter-personal Relations.name: Strict Personal Boundaries
Inter-personal Relations.description: Individuals should maintain firm boundaries in relationships and interactions, protecting their emotional, physical, and mental space from intrusion.

Inter-personal Relations.name: Flexible Boundaries
Inter-personal Relations.description: Personal boundaries should be adaptable, allowing for negotiation and adjustment depending on the context and relationships.

Inter-personal Relations.name: Permeable Boundaries
Inter-personal Relations.description: Personal boundaries should be minimal, allowing for deep connection and openness, even at the risk of emotional or personal vulnerability.

Inter-personal Relations.name: Emotional Boundaries
Inter-personal Relations.description: It is important to protect one's emotional well-being by separating personal emotions from the emotions of others and not allowing others to dictate how one feels.

Inter-personal Relations.name: Physical Boundaries
Inter-personal Relations.description: Individuals have the right to control physical access to their bodies, and clear consent should be required for any physical interaction.

Inter-personal Relations.name: Intellectual Boundaries
Inter-personal Relations.description: A person's thoughts, ideas, and opinions should be respected, and no one has the right to invalidate or impose on another's beliefs or intellectual space.

Inter-personal Relations.name: Digital Boundaries
Inter-personal Relations.description: Personal information and online interactions should be protected, with clear limits on what data is shared and how digital relationships are managed.

Inter-personal Relations.name: No Boundaries Philosophy
Inter-personal Relations.description: Human connections should be completely open and boundary-less, allowing for full access to each other’s lives, thoughts, and emotions without restrictions.

Inter-personal Relations.name: Professional Boundaries
Inter-personal Relations.description: Work relationships should have clear limits to maintain professionalism and prevent personal matters from interfering with business responsibilities.

Inter-personal Relations.name: Boundary Crossing for Growth
Inter-personal Relations.description: Occasionally crossing personal boundaries is acceptable if it leads to personal or relational growth, fostering stronger connections or self-awareness.

Inter-personal Relations.name: Consent-Based Boundaries
Inter-personal Relations.description: All personal boundaries should be defined by mutual consent, ensuring that individuals agree on how much space or access is allowed in any interaction.

Inter-personal Relations.name: Boundary Enforcement
Inter-personal Relations.description: It is essential to actively enforce personal boundaries and make clear when they are violated, to maintain respect and personal well-being.

Inter-personal Relations.name: Boundaries in Friendship
Inter-personal Relations.description: Friendships should have established boundaries to prevent emotional dependence, misunderstandings, or overstepping personal limits.

Inter-personal Relations.name: Codependency Rejection
Inter-personal Relations.description: Individuals should avoid codependent relationships where personal boundaries are blurred, and one person sacrifices their needs for another.

Inter-personal Relations.name: Cultural Boundaries
Inter-personal Relations.description: Cultural norms should define boundaries in social interactions, and people should respect those boundaries based on cultural values.

Gender Roles and Identity.name: Gender Essentialism
Gender Roles and Identity.description: Men and women have distinct, biologically determined roles and characteristics that should guide their behavior and social roles.

Gender Roles and Identity.name: Gender Fluidity
Gender Roles and Identity.description: Gender is not fixed and can change over time, allowing individuals to identify with different gender expressions throughout their life.

Gender Roles and Identity.name: Non-Binary Identity
Gender Roles and Identity.description: Gender exists beyond the male/female binary, and individuals can identify as non-binary, rejecting traditional gender categories.

Gender Roles and Identity.name: Traditional Gender Roles
Gender Roles and Identity.description: Men should provide for the family, while women should take care of the home and children, reflecting historical norms.

Gender Roles and Identity.name: Gender Abolitionism
Gender Roles and Identity.description: Society should eliminate all distinctions between genders, allowing individuals to define themselves without reference to gender.

Gender Roles and Identity.name: Transsexuality
Gender Roles and Identity.description: Individuals should have the right to transition from one gender to another through medical procedures and hormonal treatments, with legal recognition of their affirmed gender.

Gender Roles and Identity.name: Xenogenders
Gender Roles and Identity.description: Gender identity can extend beyond traditional male/female or binary categories, encompassing nonhuman-related identities and diverse, culturally-specific gender expressions.

Gender Roles and Identity.name: Radical Feminism
Gender Roles and Identity.description: Gender inequality is rooted in patriarchy, and society must radically restructure to dismantle male dominance.

Gender Roles and Identity.name: Queer Theory
Gender Roles and Identity.description: Gender and sexuality are social constructs, and society should challenge traditional views to embrace diverse identities and expressions.

Community Living.name: Intentional Communities
Community Living.description: People should live together based on shared values, pooling resources and cooperating to achieve common goals.

Community Living.name: Urban Living
Community Living.description: Living in densely populated cities provides access to culture, jobs, and social opportunities that are essential to modern life.

Community Living.name: Suburban Living
Community Living.description: Living in suburban areas offers the best balance of space, safety, and access to community services.

Community Living.name: Rural Living
Community Living.description: Living in rural areas provides peace, self-sufficiency, and a strong connection to nature, away from the pressures of urban life.

Community Living.name: Co-Housing
Community Living.description: Individuals should live in shared housing communities, where resources and responsibilities are distributed to enhance social cohesion.

Community Living.name: Gated Communities
Community Living.description: Living in a gated community provides safety, exclusivity, and control over the neighborhood’s environment.

Community Living.name: Communal Living
Community Living.description: All resources and responsibilities should be shared among a group of people living together, promoting collective ownership and equality.

Community Living.name: Co-Living
Community Living.description: Individuals should share living spaces with others, usually in urban settings, focusing on affordability, social interaction, and shared amenities.

Conflict Resolution.name: Nonviolent Communication
Conflict Resolution.description: Conflicts should be resolved through compassionate, nonjudgmental communication that promotes understanding and empathy.

Conflict Resolution.name: Mediation
Conflict Resolution.description: A neutral third party should help individuals resolve their disputes through dialogue and compromise.

Conflict Resolution.name: Litigation
Conflict Resolution.description: Legal action through the courts is the best way to resolve serious conflicts, ensuring justice and accountability.

Conflict Resolution.name: Arbitration
Conflict Resolution.description: A neutral arbitrator should make binding decisions in disputes, providing a faster and less formal alternative to court.

Conflict Resolution.name: Diplomacy
Conflict Resolution.description: Conflicts between groups or nations should be resolved through negotiations and formal agreements rather than force.

Conflict Resolution.name: Pacifism
Conflict Resolution.description: All forms of violence are morally wrong, and conflicts should be resolved through peaceful means.

Conflict Resolution.name: Militarism
Conflict Resolution.description: Conflicts should be resolved through the use of force or military action when other methods fail, as it can be the quickest way to achieve decisive outcomes.

Social Equality.name: Equal Opportunity
Social Equality.description: Everyone should have the same opportunities to succeed, regardless of their background, gender, race, or economic status.

Social Equality.name: Meritocracy
Social Equality.description: Individuals should be rewarded and advanced based on their abilities and efforts, without regard to social class, race, or other background factors.

Social Equality.name: Affirmative Action
Social Equality.description: Policies should be implemented to give historically marginalized groups preferential access to education, employment, and resources to correct past injustices.

Social Equality.name: Income Equality
Social Equality.description: Income should be distributed more evenly across society to reduce the gap between the rich and the poor, ensuring a fairer economic system.

Social Equality.name: Gender Equality
Social Equality.description: Men and women should have equal rights, responsibilities, and opportunities in all areas of life, from the workplace to personal relationships.

Social Equality.name: Racial Equality
Social Equality.description: People of all races should have equal rights and opportunities, and systemic racism should be dismantled through social and legal reforms.

Social Equality.name: Class Equality
Social Equality.description: Society should work to reduce or eliminate class distinctions, ensuring that wealth, power, and resources are distributed more equally.

Social Equality.name: LGBTQ+ Rights
Social Equality.description: People of all sexual orientations and gender identities should have equal rights and protections, including legal recognition and freedom from discrimination.

Social Equality.name: Disability Rights
Social Equality.description: People with disabilities should have equal access to all areas of life, including employment, education, and public spaces, with necessary accommodations.

Social Equality.name: Intersectionality
Social Equality.description: Social equality should account for the interconnected nature of race, gender, class, and other identities, recognizing how overlapping forms of discrimination affect individuals.

Social Equality.name: Reparations
Social Equality.description: Financial or material compensation should be provided to historically oppressed or marginalized groups to address the harm caused by past injustices.

Military Service.name: Mandatory Military Service
Military Service.description: All eligible citizens should be required to serve in the military for a period of time to foster national unity and preparedness.

Military Service.name: Volunteer Military Service
Military Service.description: Military service should be voluntary, and only those who choose to serve should be enlisted, ensuring personal freedom and choice.

Military Service.name: Conscientious Objection
Military Service.description: Individuals should have the right to refuse military service on moral or religious grounds without facing penalties or forced conscription.

Military Service.name: Selective Service for Men Only
Military Service.description: Military conscription should apply only to men, whether voluntary or conscripted.

Military Service.name: Gender Equality in Military Service
Military Service.description: Both men and women should be equally eligible for military service, whether voluntary or conscripted, to promote gender equality.

Military Service.name: Professional Military
Military Service.description: The military should consist solely of professional, full-time soldiers who have voluntarily chosen it as their career.

Military Service.name: Military Exemptions for the Wealthy
Military Service.description: Wealthy individuals should be able to avoid military service by paying a fee or hiring substitutes, as has been practiced historically in some nations.

Military Service.name: Universal Conscription in Wartime
Military Service.description: During times of war or national emergency, all eligible citizens should be subject to conscription to defend the nation, regardless of personal objections.

Military Service.name: Military Service as a Path to Citizenship
Military Service.description: Non-citizens should be allowed to gain citizenship by serving in the military, providing an opportunity for service in exchange for legal status.

Military Service.name: Abolition of Military Conscription
Military Service.description: Conscription should be completely abolished, as forcing individuals into military service violates personal freedoms and autonomy.

Military Service.name: Pacifism and Military Avoidance
Military Service.description: People should reject military service and war entirely, promoting pacifism and non-violent conflict resolution as alternatives to military action.

Military Service.name: Selective Conscription Based on Skill
Military Service.description: Only individuals with certain skills, such as technical expertise or medical training, should be conscripted, ensuring the military has the specialized abilities it needs.

Cultural Integration.name: Multiculturalism
Cultural Integration.description: Different cultures should coexist in society, with each preserving its identity while contributing to a shared national identity.

Cultural Integration.name: Cultural Assimilation
Cultural Integration.description: Immigrants and minority groups should adopt the customs and values of the dominant culture in their new society.

Cultural Integration.name: Cultural Preservation
Cultural Integration.description: Efforts should be made to preserve and protect traditional cultures from outside influences and modernization.

Cultural Integration.name: Isolationism
Cultural Integration.description: Foreign cultures and people should be viewed with suspicion, as they may threaten the established way of life.

Cultural Integration.name: Globalism
Cultural Integration.description: Cultural integration should be encouraged worldwide, with the free exchange of ideas, goods, and people across borders.

Cultural Integration.name: Cosmopolitanism
Cultural Integration.description: All human beings are members of a single global community, and people should prioritize global citizenship over national or cultural identities.

Cultural Integration.name: Cultural Appropriation
Cultural Integration.description: Borrowing elements from another culture, such as fashion, language, or rituals, is acceptable and enriches society by fostering cross-cultural understanding.

Healthcare.name: Universal Healthcare
Healthcare.description: The government should provide healthcare to all citizens, ensuring equal access to medical services regardless of income.

Healthcare.name: Private Healthcare
Healthcare.description: Healthcare should be provided by private companies, allowing competition to drive quality and efficiency, while patients pay for services.

Healthcare.name: Preventative Medicine
Healthcare.description: The focus of healthcare should be on preventing illness through lifestyle changes, regular check-ups, and early interventions.

Healthcare.name: Holistic Healthcare
Healthcare.description: Healthcare should address the whole person, integrating physical, mental, and spiritual well-being in treatments.

Healthcare.name: Alternative Medicine
Healthcare.description: Non-traditional treatments like acupuncture, herbal remedies, and homeopathy should be embraced as valid approaches to health.

Healthcare.name: Mental Health Advocacy
Healthcare.description: Mental health should be prioritized as equally important as physical health, with widespread access to psychological care.

Healthcare.name: Antipsychiatry
Healthcare.description: Mental illness should not be treated as a medical issue, and psychiatric treatments such as medication and institutionalization are harmful and oppressive.

Parenting.name: Authoritative Parenting
Parenting.description: Parents should set clear rules and expectations while also being responsive to their children’s needs and encouraging independence.

Parenting.name: Authoritarian Parenting
Parenting.description: Parents should maintain strict control over their children’s behavior, prioritizing obedience and discipline over freedom.

Parenting.name: Permissive Parenting
Parenting.description: Parents should be lenient, allowing children to make their own decisions without imposing strict rules or discipline.

Parenting.name: Helicopter Parenting
Parenting.description: Parents should closely monitor and control every aspect of their children’s lives to protect them from harm and ensure success.

Parenting.name: Free-Range Parenting
Parenting.description: Children should be given the freedom to explore the world and take risks, allowing them to develop independence and problem-solving skills.

Parenting.name: Attachment Parenting
Parenting.description: Parents should form strong emotional bonds with their children through practices like co-sleeping and baby-wearing to promote emotional security.

Education.name: Traditional Schooling
Education.description: Education should be structured and teacher-led, focusing on academic achievement, discipline, and standardized testing.

Education.name: Montessori Education
Education.description: Children should learn at their own pace through hands-on, self-directed activities, with teachers serving as guides rather than instructors.

Education.name: Progressive Education
Education.description: Education should focus on experiential learning, critical thinking, and developing social and emotional skills rather than rote memorization.

Education.name: Homeschooling
Education.description: Parents should take responsibility for their children’s education, teaching them at home and tailoring lessons to their individual needs.

Education.name: Unschooling
Education.description: Children should direct their own learning based on their interests, with minimal formal instruction or structure.

Education.name: Charter Schools
Education.description: Education should be provided by publicly funded but independently run schools that operate outside traditional school district regulations.

Workplace Culture.name: Flat Hierarchy
Workplace Culture.description: Workplaces should minimize levels of hierarchy, promoting collaboration and equality among all employees regardless of rank.

Workplace Culture.name: Traditional Corporate Culture
Workplace Culture.description: Workplaces should maintain clear hierarchies and formal structures, with strict roles, responsibilities, and protocols.

Workplace Culture.name: Work-Life Integration
Workplace Culture.description: Work and personal life should be seamlessly integrated, with flexible schedules and environments that accommodate both.

Workplace Culture.name: Remote Work
Workplace Culture.description: Employees should be allowed to work from home or any location of their choice, with a focus on results rather than physical presence.

Workplace Culture.name: Collaborative Culture
Workplace Culture.description: Workplaces should emphasize teamwork and shared decision-making, encouraging employees to contribute ideas and work together toward goals.

Workplace Culture.name: Performance-Based Culture
Workplace Culture.description: Employees should be rewarded and promoted based on their performance, with a focus on measurable outcomes and meritocracy.

Workplace Culture.name: Location-Based Compensation
Workplace Culture.description: Employee compensation should be adjusted based on the cost of living in their location

Workplace Culture.name: Digital Nomadism
Workplace Culture.description: People should embrace the freedom of working remotely and traveling the world, using technology to live and work from anywhere.

Workplace Culture.name: Gig Economy
